The front desk staff is also extremely polite and very quick to make great recommendations if you haven't been to Charleston before.As someone who was long skeptical of b&b's, Elliot House really changed my whole mindset by providing a perfect experience. As a solo traveler on this trip, I couldn't have asked for anything else. Highly recommended.We came to Charleston during peek season (tourist and wedding) so all of the hotels were a bit pricy. I reserved a queen room for my boyfriends birthday, where we spent a Saturday and Sunday night.The hotel - I selected Elliott House because it wasn't quite a B&B but had that feeling. Some of the B&B's seem just a little bit too antiquated for me so I thought this would be a nice compromise, and I liked the cute courtyard. They do wine and cheese reception in the afternoon and complimentary breakfast which can be delivered to your room or to the courtyard. The wine and cheese reception and the complimentary breakfast were both nice touches but could have been better. The cheese are cubes of cheese you would get at the grocery store, and the wine tasted watered down. The breakfast options were only things like bagel, cereal, yogurt (no eggs and bacon here). They do have room service that they can deliver from 82 Queen, which we did not get to try. They recommend parking in the garage across the street but offer no validation or discount, which is a shame because it's $20 a day.The room - I spoke to one of the people at the front desk and they told me a little bit about the rooms. We selected the cheapest option which they said was on the street so it could be a little loud in the morning with delivery trucks. This was not a problem Sunday morning but it was very loud Monday morning when garbage got picked up. The room itself was very small, which was fine. The bed was comfortable and the bathroom was clean and nice. There were scuff marks on the wall, but other than that the room was very nice and the turndown service was great.The location - this location was PERFECT. It's really in the action of Charleston with easy access to anywhere you want to go. Charleston isn't very large to begin with, but having this hotel in between King and Meeting street and on the south end of the peninsula worked out great.The staff - VERY nice. I was able to get a AAA discount for our hotel which dramatically reduced the price. I love that they will bring the breakfast straight to your room. We didn't really have any issues but I'm sure if we did they would have been very accommodating.This is an absolutely charming little bed and breakfast! It's the perfect place to stay for a true "Charleston" vacation, and it just so happens to be in an unbeatable location. Steps away from Elliot House, there is Queen 82, Poogan's Porch (a fabulous brunch and dinner spot), as well as the always talked-about Husk Restaurant (I went to all three- see reviews). You can also walk to the market, the pier, King Street and East Bay Street with complete ease.Onto the property itself- it's so quaint and lovely! They have a gorgeous courtyard where they serve complimentary wine and cheese from 5-7pm everyday with lush foliage, a gazebo and picturesque little nooks and crannies. The room I stayed in was very spacious with beautiful victorian decor throughout. It actually reminded me of my grandmother's southern home (who, by the way, has fabulous interior design taste!). The bathroom was extremely clean and rich with modern finishings. The only thing I would suggest that guests bring with them is a sleeping mask (our room never got totally dark due to the lighting from Husk and the courtyard out front, but then again, that probably had a lot to do with the location of our specific room). Housekeeping was always amazing, the bed was very comfortable and I have no complaints about my trip- just great memories!The last two things I would like to add is that the complimentary bike rentals were awesome (the bike rides were actually the highlight of my trip... you should try it!) and the customer service was phenomenal. When we arrived on the property, the nice young man working at the front office spent a good 10 minutes suggesting all sorts of good places to eat, visit and experience on our trip. He also handed us a printout of Charleston history and offered a few maps with some routes that he highlighted for us to enjoy. Overall, I could not have asked for a more accommodating, friendly-staffed and equally charming bed & breakfast to stay at while on vacation. If you want to enjoy a small, lovely bed & breakfast that treats you like family, then Elliot House is definitely your spot! I will most certainly stay here again when I return. :)Clean and private rooms that look to have been recently renovated. Very comfortable and relaxing. It's a good mix of a hotel and B&B. The staff are extremely friendly and they offer a wine and cheese hour every evening. The continental breakfast is served to your room or to a table in their courtyard. I highly recommend this business and will be back in the future. Unfortunately, there is no street parking due to the historic aspect of where this is located but their is a parking garage directly across the street that's $20/day.Where to start.... Let's see, the site we booked the hotel on had a 100% positive feedback.. We love charleston, been many times, always wanted to stay here but pricey. So ended up booking it on a whim and showing up the same day. The outside pergola was dirty, the "pool" which was the size of a king size bed.. Speaking of the beds, in the room the size are twin beds. Not good for two adults.. Anyway walked into a very pleasant guy at front desk. Went into the room and first thing we saw were dead cockroaches on the bathroom floor. For 300$ a night "off season" what a joke.. So many fun and beautiful places to stay in charleston, skip this one! Oh yeah!!!! A little advice to the women cleaning the rooms and delivering breakfast. You work in customer service, wouldn't kill you to smile and say good morning back to a guest!We're staying at the Elliott House for the second time now. The place is clean and the location is very convenient between one of our favorite restaurants (Poogans Porch) and a nice little French wine bar ( Bin 152). The rooms are fairly spacious for the price you pay per night. Try to avoid rooms 10 and 21 as they are facing Queen St unless you want to use the garbage trucks as your personal alarm clock. This is a common challenge with many hotels in Charleston but it seems even more noisy in those rooms. The breakfast is good, I especially like the classy touch of ceramic coffee cups and silver coffee pots. It reminds me of the "old-timey" breakfasts you're served in Europe. We will try some other hotels the next few times we're back in Charleston but the Elliott House is definitely a very solid alternative if you're looking for an above average stay between Market and the Battery.My wife and I loved staying at the Elliott House Inn for a few days during our recent trip to Charleston. The people are very friendly, the location is very convenient (parking garage across the street and walking distance to everything in the city), and the rooms were very nice and clean. The price was also very affordable.**Helpful Hint: Free breakfast and daily wine happy hours are included with your stay. Even if you want to get out of the Inn for either event, it is great to have the option.The guy at the desk was extremely nice & helpful. I would suggest to get a room in the back Bc of all the noise. Rooms are quite small.Honestly the "breakfast" was no good. They should just offer coffee. Wine & cheese was cheap. They should just do away with that as well. We had a comfortable king size bed. The location is amazing though. Would probably not go back.Elliott House has a lot to recommend it. At the top of the list is location - so many excellent restaurants within two blocks. The staff is friendly and efficient. The rooms are large and comfortable. The 5 PM wine and cheese in the courtyard is pleasant, even if the actual wine and cheese is indifferent. However, you have to understand that Charleston is a city were all maintenance is deferred and casual scruff is part of the charm. If you are expecting the sleek spotlessness of a spanking new property you will not only be disappointed, you will be horrified. There some people I would never recommend this to and others I would highly recommend stay here. I think you two camps know who you are.My husband and I were in town for just one night & we had a great time here! I love to stay in historic B&B's & this one was unique, charming, & beautiful in it's own way. We parked our car across the street in the parking garage ($20 for overnight, but we didn't mind) & walked everywhere we went. The room was quaint & comfy & the bed was cozy. We enjoyed the free wine & cheese reception that they serve at 5pm every day. Our favorite part was the breakfast they brought to our room the next morning. It was so nice to have breakfast in bed! Not a whole lot of food, but we enjoyed what they served & it was enough to fill us up until lunch. The people were nice & very helpful. Will definitely stay here again on our next visit to Charleston!Another great location. Parking garage across the street (paid). The property is small but has a great lay out including a swimming pool. My room was small I suppose in that the king size bed took up almost all of it. The decor was a solid balance of historic southern and modern convenience. I thought the bathroom was fantastic. I enjoyed the custom breakfast delivery in the morning and the inviting lobby in the afternoon. The staff are really nice and extremely knowledgeable. You're also walking distance to pretty much everything you need to or want to see on the peninsula. Best of all you are near some of the best restaurants serving some of the best food in South Carolina if not the entire Southeast. If you're in to history ask for the guy that happens to be a historian and also works here. He knew everything about everything. He printed out his summaries and suggestions based on our conversations from his personal notes. Those few pages ended up being a great resource.Excellent location, but that's about it. The rooms are small with rather basic amenities for the price. The breakfast should be termed "why bother". In a town noted for its food, Costco muffins and cold cereal do not cut it. The only fruit was half a grapefruit that was not sectioned with the sharpest utensil a butter knife. At least the coffee was good. The wine and cheese in the afternoon was also uninspired. Pleasant desk staff.My favorite historic bed & breakfast in Charleston. Staff is impeccable, rooms are beautiful. I always recommend these accommodations when staying in Charleston.I spent 2 nights at the Elliot House Inn. You can't beat the location, you can walk to many shops/restaurants/attractions. Bikes are offered for you to explore the city on your own. Another plus, the evening wine/cheese reception. Clean rooms and helpful staff. The breakfast was just enough food to begin your day. My next trip to charleston will include another stay here.Price wasn't bad, considering ALL of Charleston is expensive. In hind-sight we shoulda done a VRBO.com rental. We rented two rooms...one king for ourselves, and one queen fo our parents. Room #28 was the king suite, and it was fantastic. Beautiful decor, built in cabinets, nice TV, and a couch. Room #25 was the queen suite, and it was disappointing. There was a sewer pipe running the length of the ceiling, hardly any decor, smelled like mold and the window-view was a plaster wall of the restaurant next door, less than 3 feet away. One morning a cockroach (Palmetto bug as they call it) ran across the floor.The nice girl at the front desk let me see room 11 as a possible alternative, but it was just as bad. Later, i voiced my displeasure to the GM, and she refunded a nice portion of the rental, so i have to give them credit for that. She told me each room is individually owned and decorated, and that Elliott House simply serves as the on-site management. Fair enough, but i think they should set a certain standard for room decor...and definitely get rid of the moldy smell.Also, you had to ask for an iron (which leaked water like a sieve), and ironing board (which was damn-near broken). The breakfast is typical continental, but at least they deliver it to your room.Adorable little B&B in downtown Charleston. The staff was very accommodating and the room was very charming. I will definitely be staying here again. There is an outdoor Jacuzzi and they bring breakfast and coffee to your room in the morning. It's also located right downtown near a ton of amazing James Beard nominated/awarded restaurants. A sweet little gem.We stayed for 3 nights in February and loved it. The only thing that we thought that they could improve on was breakfast. You only get a couple of choices and it's the same choices every day.. When I say "a few choices" I mean yogurt and muffin or beagle and half of a grapefruit.. I was starving by 9am. Other than that everything was perfect, walking distance to everything.Stayed here for the first time for five days immediately before Christmas so we were there long enough to get a good feel for the physical comforts of the place as well as the service. On both counts it deserves solid marks. Rooms are adequate and comfortable and we found the staff prepared to go above and beyond what is called for to see that your stay is enjoyable. Location is the most compelling factor as it is within a short to reasonable walk of all of Charleston's downtown attractions and districts. In a word it is convenient to anywhere you would want to eat, shop, or visit. Municipal parking right across the street adds to the convenience if you have a car. Parking at $22 a day is also reasonable given the location. Breakfasts were light which was great for us as we spent the rest of our time in town eating our way through all of Charleston's excellent restaurants. Wine and cheese at night was a nice way to close out the day if we were around that time in the late afternoon or early evening. The secret of the Elliott House however is the pool/jacuzzi which seems to draw criticism from some reviewers. After a long day on your feet walking to all of the attractions near the Elliott House a relaxing session in the hot waters of the jacuzzi with the water jets going is all you need to fully relax and get your feet and legs ready to do it all again the next day. The courtyard is also a quiet and peaceful place to unwind and relax between walking trips around town. Finally, the Elliott House is an inn/BandB and does not pretend to offer all the things that a full service hotel makes available. As such, the rooms and the TVs are not huge and many of the things a seasoned traveler expects to find in a full service hotel are not in the room. However, as an inn/BandB it is more than adequate and deserves all four of the stars we gave it in this rating.My GF and I booked two nights at the Elliot House. The location is ideal for a Charleston getaway. This gem of an Inn is located within walking distance of almost everything (restaurants, museum s, shopping, etc.). Upon arrival you will be greeted by either Grace or Neil both local Charleston folk with a touch of southern hospitality. Grace was an absolute sweet heart and very helpful with all our accommodations, while Neil was a history buff and provide great insight of what to see and do, he provided a useful map and essay he wrote about Charleston. The overall hotel was very clean and well maintained with a picturesque scene. The breakfast was wonderful they would deliver it to your room at any time you desired. Overall the only issue I had was you had to pay 20$ a day for parking which is a parking garage across the street, to me this should just be included in the price of the hotel. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for a Charleston getaway.
review_content_20: This place is truly a hidden gem in Charleston! Was in town for a wedding and we needed a hotel for Thursday-Sunday but Mills House Hotel (where the block of rooms was) only had Friday-Sunday available. Although Mills House was nice, I would have much preferred all 3 nights at Elliott House Inn if I had known how amazing their rooms and amenities were.A LOT of thought has been put into all upgrades in the rooms.  The bathrooms have top of the line fixturing, the linens are crisp and white, and the room was quaint and clean.  You even have a small private patio!This isn't even touching upon the warm pastries, yogurt, coffee carafe, and juice delivered to your room on a silver tray in the morning.  And that is in addition to the wine and cheese nightly happy hour in the courtyard.Aside from being next to the neighboring restaurant, housekeeping is a little noisy in the morning.  But, this is something I have come to look past as it happens in every hotel that I stay in no matter where I travel.  I cannot wait to make another trip to Charleston and stay here again.  Will definitely recommend to all of my friends and family.My husband and I stayed here for our anniversary at the end of April.  It was the only bed and breakfast type inn we could find with any availability one month before our trip.  It was really nice that they have a 24 hour concierge, so someone was there to greet us after our late arrival Thursday night.  The courtyard is quite pretty, as well as the rest of the exterior of the inn.  The biggest issue we had with Elliott House was the breakfast.  It is nice that they bring it to you on a tray in the morning, but you only get to choose from cereal, bagel, Activia yogurt and granola.  I feel like the amount you pay for the hotel should yield a nicer selection of breakfast items.  I really would rather that they save the trouble of delivering breakfast and just have a really nice hot continental breakfast.  The first morning we ordered the bagels with cream cheese and received no cream cheese. The third morning we ordered tea and coffee, and received hot water with no tea.  Definitely not an issue to totally ruin our experience, but definitely an annoyance.  Other than a few minor issues, the inn was pleasant.  The room was nice and comfortable.  The location was also very convenient, directly next door to two restaurants, one being the very highly acclaimed Husk (where we did dine and had a great experience)We absolutely enjoyed our stay at the Elliott House.  Can't say enough good stuff about the staff... everyone we encountered was exceptional.  The Inn is everything we hoped it would be... quaint, cozy, perfectly located.  Although we didn't have the opportunity to partake of the wine & cheese reception, it was nice to know it was available.  We had read the reviews re: noise from the adjoining restaurants and early morning deliveries... we experienced none of that.  Of course, our room was at the back of the property overlooking the courtyard.  We also read of the musty smelling rooms... It's Charleston!  It's humid!  ;-)  Room delivery on the continental breakfast is a nice touch!  Yes, it's a very basic offering, but it is sufficient.  You want more than that?  Walk a couple blocks over to Toast.  My only recommendation for the Inn would be to power wash the stairwells a little more often.  They were looking a little rough.  Want the rest of my wish list?  Adding a full length mirror to the rooms would be helpful, and an in-room mini fridge would be awesome!Spent a night at  this little gem, located between Meeting and King St. We were a day early meeting up with family and booked a room for the same day. The staff was very friendly and personable. The room was charming, comfortable and super clean, with a great hot shower (not always the case with historic setting). A nice continental breakfast is included (served either in room or courtyard), and the free beach cruisers were an excellent way to tour the beautiful surroundings and historic homes. Definitely worth a repeat visit when in Charleston again!If you like to be awakened EVERY morning at 6:30 by the garbage truck, you will enjoy this place. If you enjoy the sound of a pressure washer 15 feet away in the courtyard while you are eating a minimal breakfast at 8:30 in the morning, you will adore this place. The rooms are ok, nothing special. It is convenient to all the shops and restaurants in Charleston, but the ambiance is below average.I had to stay for business, so my visit was quick and didn't have the luxury to enjoy the outdoor courtyard for daily wine and cheese. It's located in the heart of downtown Charleston within walking distance to shops, restaurants and sight seeing.  The parking isn't convenient as it is across the street in a public parking deck, but the Inn Staff suggested I pull into their small driveway to drop off my suitcase before parking.  The overnight parking costed about $20.  The room itself was nice and quaint although my upstairs neighbors had their TV a bit loud until late at night.  However, the A/C system was so loud it drowned out any outside noise. It had a nice back patio that might be enjoyable with room service.  I didn't care too much for the cheap quaility of linens especially the bath towels. I prefer a more plush bath towel with washcloths and bath mat which was missing.  The cute little danish, yogurt and tea was a nice touch in the morning delivered to your room at your designated time. The courtyard had a cute little pool that was more for the visual than for swimming since it was full of leaves and not warm enough to swim. I don't know if I will stay again as if I'm going to stay in an Inn or Bed & Breakfast I would rather explore other options in Charleston.

review_content: We arrived here as hurricane Joaquin was beginning to ease up. We couldn't have made it into town if it weren't for a Uber driver that knew the back streets. When we arrived we needed a drink and since nothing was opened they brought a carafe of wine, pimiento cheese spread, crackers and fruit. Each morning is a free breakfast that is much better than you see at other hotels. In the evening is a wine and hors d'oeuvres. The hotel is in a great location and our room had a balcony. We were very happy with our decision to stay here once the weather got better. I would recommend this hotelWhen I stayed in Charleston I wanted quaint. A stay with a place with four poster beds, in the historic district, in an old building. Well I got it. Not sure if it was a good choice in the Meeting Street Inn however. I think it might stem from the disconnect between $180 a night and the level of appointments that I received. Now don't get me wrong, the staff was friendly and the exterior of the place was equally pretty. They had a nice courtyard and architecture that was very fitting with the rest of the area. I got my 4 post bed (that was very comfy), but there were some downsides. First off - the breakfast was really bad. The food was just....inedible. Perhaps my first morning they were off but I wasn't about to try it again. Rock-hard boiled eggs, stale muffins and this casserole...thing. Secondly - the wifi was uselessly bad. I was on the 4th floor towards the back so I guess their existing infrastructure didn't reach that far back. It's 2016 guys - I need wifi to work, not just play. The room itself was definitely old and worn, but it was clean. Very small, kinda dirty porch out the back. Housekeeping was very friendly. Can't say I would come back but I am not their target demographic - I am sure they will be fine.I came here with my daughter on a last minute get away, and as she said to me, "This place alone makes me want to come back."  I have been to the Charleston area many times, and though the weather this time was not friendly, the staff here certainly was, and we felt at home here immediately.  The value was very good...great breakfast included (loved the ham and Brie sandwiches), afternoon wine  and cheese (the pimento cheese was excellent); but most of all, the staff felt like friends after just a few days.  People always make the experience what it is after all.  Darren and Neeko (I'm sorry if that's not spelled right) not only put upwith our craziness from the beginning, but were just genuinely cool people with good taste in music, actors, comedians, and the latest in scarf/ascot trends. Even out of the ring...you guys rock.  Every person on staff here was extremely warm and helpful.  The Inn is quaint, with so much history, and perfectly located.  It has been a pleasure.The BEST, MOST ACCOMODATING, WONDERFUL people you will meet in Charleston! We had booked at another hotel that turned out to be incredible unsatisfactory. Fortunately, we were able to find The Meeting Street Inn. We were greeted by Keith and Darren (aka "Broadway") who were wonderful at making sure we were comfortable and having a delightful stay.  They allowed us to go up and view the room first, worked out our reservation so we did not have to change rooms for the following night since we were a last minute walk in, had a bellhop for bags and someone to valet the car since parking was about 2 blocks away. Keith was able to help us book a few different tours and Darren was always there to help with any questions or recommendations of places in the city - in general good-hearted people who care about the travelers in their hotel - great people to know and a splendid staff.The hotel itself is unbelievably charming, a true feel of southern hospitality - just look at the pictures!The stay included daily HOT breakfast buffet AND a cocktail hour with free wine, cheese and crackers : ) It is also conveniently located to everything - Kings Street Shopping, Market Place, East Blvd. - plus Toast is right next door!Best tip about this place: they have huge, fluffy, clean and comfortable towels - pool side and in your room!We love this place and the staff!  Betty, Jo, Lee, Lorenzo, and January--by the time we left they felt like friends.  Terrific food.  Relaxing. Close to everything we wanted to do in charleston.  Wonderful roomNice older hotel with charming decor. If you want something a little out of the ordinary with old city charm this is it!!! The staff was so polite and extremely helpful.... Looking forward to our next stay.This place is awesome!! I was here for work and stayed 3 nights at Charleston Place for a convention and then we switched to The Meeting Street Inn because my family also came with me and we wanted a real Charleston experience. The staff here is amazing, super friendly. Wine and cheese is served at 5 every evening. There is a van that can take you anywhere you want to go which was nice because it rained a lot the week we were here. And the breakfast has everything you can imagine. Would stay here again for sure! Plus the location is right in the middle of everything. Love the homey feel!We stayed for 1 night at this hotel last month. I was looking for a reasonably-priced place with some southern charm, and this was it! The location is great - within walking distance of many restaurants, shops, and the waterfront. The breakfast buffet was the best I have ever seen or tasted. The wine & cheese hour was delightful. The room was clean, and the decor was charming, along with a wonderful courtyard area. My only complaint is that they do not have a pool. They have a very small hot tub in the courtyard, which nobody wanted to use in the 100+ degree temps in July. I would recommend The Meeting Street Inn to anyone!We  were so pleased with our stay.  I am very fussy about cleanliness and this inn lived up to my standards.  The breakfast was varied and good; the afternoon wine with the cheese and fruit platter was fresh and plentiful and afternoon lemonade with homemade cookies hit the spot.  The staff is courteous and helpful.  Located in the heart of the city enabled us to walk to all our destinations throughout the weekend.  I can't wait to come back for another visit!It is cheap for a reason! Wait, did I say "cheap?" Cause our two-night stay there ran us about $400 (including parking and taxes). No I don't think it is cheap at all, and I would rather spend a little more and stayed at a better B&B.Now let me be clear about the positives: The people working there were very nice and helpful and the room was clean. It is also in a prime location, but you know what? Pretty much all Inns and hotels in the historic center are in prime location as everything is in walking distance.Now for the negatives that were however not deal-breakers, just good mood breakers: 1.The parking situation is not ideal. Their parking garage for which we were charged an extra $14/night, is two blocks away (did we know that? no). They do have golf carts that transport as back and forth and the drivers are very nice. However, our second day there we came back from the beach to find to open spot in that lot. Really? If you charge people, you better do the math and leave their spots available for the total of their stay. It seemed that this happens quite often, judging from the staff reaction when we told them. By the time we went to the hotel, and the golf cart guy followed us back (to resolve the situation another car was leaving). Point is, this should not have happened.2. Yes the breakfast sucks but I don't care that much. We are staying in a foodie town, so I don't have to rely on their breakfast or their "wine and cheese" reception we chose not to attend (went to a wine bar instead). But at one point their water dispenser carafe broke (again from what I was told), so there was no water. Next morning they ran out of forks (!). There was no seating available in our outside during breakfast.3. The bathroom was clean, counter large, but bathtub way outdated. No nice cutie bathroom lotions/no hair conditioner. AC was loud. TV was small. No pen in the room. Room felt stuffy after a day. People, you can't just add a canopy bed and some flower wallpaper and call this charming OK?Dealbreakers:1. Slotted 4rth floor  "balcony"; No a/c in the elevator: it was like a sauna in there; did not know which evil to go for, the elevator or the stairs and received all the heat from the a/c motors next to them.2. Most important: the overall "feel" of this place. Basically it is a half step-upped and overpriced Days Inn (which is next door AND has its own parking lot). That is not what I have in mind when I reserve a room in a B&B in Charleston, and when I pay all this money, sorry.The hotel is very historic and gives you a glimpse into the way life used to be. The room was clean and adequate. What you really pay for is the historic southern charm and location. The location was just about perfect. I don't have children but I would say this is not a family friendly hotel. There is an oversized hot tub in the small courtyard but that's it for entertainment. The old lobby has antique furniture and they offer complimentary breakfast and happy hour alcohol drinks. Plenty of Southern charm and flare but don't expect much luxury. I would stay there again but I don't feel an obligation of loyalty.Bkfst a disappointment.  I thought this was a B & B so I arranged my morning sched to be sure to have time to enjoy a gourmet bkfst.  Alas, it was the usual fare you'd get on the interstate; small boxes of cereal, styrofoam bowls, eggs made hours or days in advance, etc.  Quite a letdown.Staff not too friendly, either.  Barely looked up when I entered the room and this happened each time.For the price this place was great!! The staff was very helpful and the rooms were very charming.  Darren Whitaker was the gentleman that helped us and we were very impressed with the service we got while we were here.  Nice centrally located place.Very charming hotel. They actually use real keys. It was very charming and neat. The front desk owners/ employees were too busy to get up and acknowledge me or anyone else that was standing at the front desk.   They were very put out. Definitely when they get to you mentality.  Very poor service for 220 a night. Won't go back!We were in Charleston for a wedding and stayed here for the cheaper option. The location is killer the rooms are completely solid. Free WI-FI is always great. I breakfast exceeded my expectations, though I should note they were not high. Parking was super simple across the street. Staff was average. Not horrible at all but nothing that was all that great either. 3 stars for room and staff. Extra star for cost and location.No complaints here! Super close to King Street, adorable and cozy rooms with canopy beds and even a little balcony, (super) friendly staff, and a fine continental breakfast. There's even a jacuzzi, and outside there is a nice space to sit and relax. You can either find street parking or park across the street ($12 a night).  The price was reasonable, especially for a holiday weekend (about $129). Great old-style charm!checked into the hotel last night. I didn"t realize until today when i got a pop-up from my credit card company that they had over-charged us biig-time. we were quoted $159/night and we were charged something quite different when I did the math it came out to  about $240/night (including tax). Charleston has a  13% hotel  tax  so it looks like an overcharge of about $80/night --ouch! We went to the front desk and were told that we were charged the high season rate which begin tonite  and we need to talk to the manager--he comes in later.  we shall se how that goes.All in all, after staying at The Mansion on Forsyth Park in Savannah it's hard to say anything great about this hotel--rather run-down and in need of a facelift. a little cleaning all around wouldn't hurt either.I will follow up with another review when we depart.Great place to stay! Rooms are very pretty and a perfect location in the historic district.I loved staying at this inn. We were on vacation in Savannah and Charleston and made the decision to just find historic inns in the center of town so we could walk everywhere. Not all historic inns are this nice and cozy, and clean. But this was very well maintained, A lot of antique charm and cool side porches that lead to your room. The bed was comfortable and had a canopy. There was a nice outdoor patio for having your morning coffee before heading out around town. Just a unique experience. And the price was reasonable for the location.Good old Charleston aesthetic,If one is going to stay in Charleston, it is great not to stay in a modern room. The Inn was old, yet smelled nice, much better then the modern rooms we stayed in down the coast :-) The wooden walkways and stairs creaked, the wall paper and lamps were ghastly and appropriate. The furniture was comfortable dark leather chairs and dark old fashioned dressers to hide the TV. Central to why I wrote this review was the beds :-D, tall four poster beds with the crochet netting. You know in all those movies where people hid under the bed, and no one can fit under a modern bed at all, so I makes you wonder where these beds are that anyone could hide under. Well 3 or 4 people could comfortably hide under these giant old bed frames. We laughed when we opened the door to our room, we thought it was so quaint and neat'O and oh yeah romantic. A plus, they have cheese and crackers and wine at 5:30 pm and nice sweet bread goodies, bagels, fruit and coffee etc .. from 7 to 10ish am. And of course it is walking distance to the waterfront, and all the old shops, and everywhere one wanders while visiting the lovely old town of Charleston.P.s. I'm not sure why I didn't give them 5 stars. Then even had good WiFi, and I think they might have a ghost or two.
review_content_20: A very quaint hotel.  After checking out the Miller Hotel down the block and comparing rooms I decided to stay at the Meting.  The Miller's room smelled liked cooking grease and the beds were like cardboard, and they wanted $200+.  The Meeting is a huge mom and pop hotel.  You're surrounded by antique charm the moment you hit the lobby.  The staff is pleasant and easy to deal with. My room was a nice size, very clean with no deodorant odor and came with a queen.  The queen mattress was a bit high off the floor..  it reminded me of when I was a kid and I used to take running starts, jump and do a rolling tumble on my parent's bed because it was so high off the floor.  But the mattress felt comfortable and I fell asleep easily so the height size was more amusing than it was a pain.  Television was adequate.  No electric outlet was supplied by my desk and I had to work my laptop wireless (supplied on the house) on my bed.  I attended the nightly wine and cheese party the staff throws at 5:30 p.m. and it's quite nice.  You socialize with other guests, drink wine and eat some mediocre tuna spread and spicy mushroom, which really isn't important since the food is just a pretext to relax, or relax and chat.  I even met a couple from Park Slope who were with their family from Knoxville and Birmingham.  Continental breakfast is also on the hotel.  There's a parking lot across the street that charges $12 a day for hotel guests and you're situated right in the middle of the historic district.My only complaints, which might be moot because of certain circumstances is that their ac/heater only does cool, cold and very hot.  I was there during the cold snap which I understand is a rare occurrence and had it on very hot.  Also, you're given a key to your room, not a smart card.  A key that fits into a hall and closet lock on the front door.  A lock someone like me can easily card open.  However, I am a native Brooklyn and am therefore naturally.I will go back again later this year when it gets warmer.Phenomenal location and a wonderful, generous staff that went out of its way to be helpful at every turn. The folks at the front desk made great recommendations, helped us sort out car rental confusion and then a mistaken parking ticket among other things, and were easy-going and friendly throughout. Accommodations were spacious and while there was limited natural light as noted by other reviewers there were plenty of lamps and a private back porch so we could leave the door open when desired. It was perfect for our needs and we would return the Inn in a heartbeat on future Charleston travels.I took a trip to Charleston with my family recently and stayed at the Meeting Street Inn.  A friend had recommended it and I am sure glad she did.  It was really quaint and in a great location.  There was so much to see around the Inn.  I would recommend it to anyone who is going to Charleston.If you're staying in Charleston, this is a great place to spend your money.The hotel is not cheap, but it has a lot of advantages. One caveat though: this hotel is not new, and it shows. If you're looking for a polished high-class experience then go somewhere else. That's not what Charleston is about though, this hotel has some charm.It's centrally located, just south of the City Market and it comes with parking across the street. They serve wine and cheese in the evenings as well as  pastries in the mornings.cute little inn with more character than one of those big chain-hotels. and by character, i don't mean nastiness - the room we stayed in was very clean and relatively spacious. great location as it is walking distance to all the main tourist sights of downtown charleston. wine and cheese reception daily. they also have breakfast in the morning but we didn't get up in time for that, since we were still on pacific time. oh and free wifi!

review_content: We typically stay at mid-range hotels when we travel but this hotel was the one of choice for our daughter's wedding.We felt like royalty.  Service and the people were amazing, courteous, friendly and anything you needed they were glad to do so.Rooms were spacious and clean and had many amenities.  Yes we did perhaps pay for them but was so nice to experience.Each afternoon is a wine and cheese hour, breakfast included and delivered each morningWe will definitely come back to here when visitingYou can walk to many shops, restaurants and sitesStopped in for a drink and a bite to eat while in town on business...ended up meeting there Food and Bev manager Rob who really made us feel at home. Will most definitely be staying and dining here anytime were in Charleston. Incredible food, remarkable hospitality and a rooftop. Thanks again Rob.Best rooftop sunset views in the city. Full bar and restaurant with two separate outside padios. Nice unique place that is still undiscovered by the tourists let along the locals to bring friends or a date.The Good:-Location- Great location, with an entrance right off of King Street--dining, shopping, and sites are all close by, along with the College of Charleston's campus. -The Room- As others have said, the rooms are more like condos. They are huge! I thought I booked a standard room, but I got a living room connected to a full kitchen. There were utensils, pots and pans, and other kitchen items to use. It would certainly be possible to cook a simple meal. -The Treats: Wine and cheese in the evening and cookies and milk before bed--what could be better?! Maybe a specialized breakfast picnic basket delivered to your room.....? Well they have that too! You can choose from a variety of pastries, cereals, and bagels, and drinks.The Bad:-The Rooftop Terrace- So disappointing! The lounge chairs are nice, but it greatly lacks the essential rooftop amenity--views! All you can see is roofing -The Housekeeping- While the complimentary treats are nice, Restoration could up their game when it comes to details. For example, under the bathroom sink, there was a tissue left behind (Ew). Also, when I opened the vanity kit that usually includes cotton balls and q-tips, it was empty. It wasn't a huge deal, but it made me wonder what else they forgot to do. The In-Between:-The Service - It was either terrific or horrible. During the day there was a young woman who lacked the hospitality that one needs to work at the front desk of a hotel. She answered questions if prompted, but was not very helpful. For example, when the printer she said guests were welcome to use ran out of ink, she did not offer a solution. However, when I asked another front desk member that night, he was able to print from a different location. This leads me to the opposite end of their service spectrum; the second person at the front desk was extremely friendly, as was the man who showed me to my room and turn-down service.  4 stars because the good parts were so good. The bad parts were disappointing, but not total deal breakers.They turned this condo complex into a hotel so your room are huge! The prices was on the lower end and breakfast served to your room each morning was great. The staff on hand was very knowledgeable and the location was right in the middle of everything you want.Absolutely loved this place!  Spacious, clean, private patio, full bath & half, full kitchen (stocked with both tap & sparking water, and soda), living room, and dining area.  Evening wine & cheese, cookies at 9:00 pm, and the best thing ever, your breakfast basket waiting for you in the morning outside your door!  Staff was friendly, laid back, and helpful; everything you would expect in Charleston.Incredible place to stay in Charleston! Absolutely worth the splurge! The rooms are gorgeous with exposed brick, modern appliances, and plush furniture. The whole place was more like an apartment than a hotel room. The bathroom felt like a spa. The bed was huge and comfy, There were two flat screen TVs with tons of channels. The kitchen was fully stocked with silverware, plates, glasses, servingware, etc. The wifi was free and fast. Service staff were friendly and accommodating. Charleston is a beautiful city worth visiting and you absolutely should stay at ROK - unfortunately it is hard to leave the room once you are there, it's that perfect.- these guys are first class - best hotel experience I've ever had- the staff bends over backwards and goes way above and beyond to ensure each guest's needs are met (and exceeded)- each room is unlike any hotel you've ever seen; there's definitely more of a "condo" feel to the rooms...ridiculously well decorated. very comfortable furniture - the location is perfect. walkable to anywhere on king, down to east bay, over to the market...central location. right in the middle of where you want to be - despite the busy location, they have expertly laid out the formation of each condo to feel very private and secluded. you're not able to look out your window and see anyone else's room...even on your deck (yes, several of the rooms have large decks fully furnished with outdoor furniture), you feel like you're in your backyard, or in the seclusion of your private high rise - I can't emphasize how great the staff is...you'll really have to see it and experience it to believe it. the amenities are essentially limitless. free breakfast delivered to your door each morning, along with the paper. ipads and apple tv's available to be set up and delivered to your room (no charge), bikes (think beach cruiser, with a basket in front) are available to borrow on the house and they even have milk and cookies on a nightly basis...after their wind and cheese offerings feet evening...unbelievable! you can't beat this place - this place is constantly sold out...it's s definite boutique experience. there are only 16 rooms as of Feb. 2015, but they're currently undergoing some major expansion, including an in-house spa (!!!)- I can't wait to stay here on my next trip to charleston. once you stay here, it's tough to imagine staying anywhere else!I love this place. So gorgeous!! The staff was so helpful. Someone at the front desk walked us to our room and before we got off the elevator he had planned out out whole night with a slew of bars and restaurant recommendations and scenic walks to take there. He knew what vibe and crowd we were looking for and mapped it all out for us. I couldn't believe how cute the picnic basket of breakfast was. It was delivered right to our door. Perfect downtown location.  Amazing rooftop and beautiful and modern designed rooms that include a large kitchen and living room.My husband and I had a great stay here. The rooms were huge and very comfortable. Great customer service. We were going to the beach and they provided us with beach chairs and beach towels. They really go above and beyond to make sure your stay is comfortable and easy. We will be back!Wow. What a perfect place to stay while visiting Charleston, SC. We parked our car and forgot about it for the whole weekend. The four of us shared a two bed/ two bath room with a massive kitchen/ dining area. I wish my house were this nice! It felt like we were staying in an upscale condo. The windows had wrap around views of King Street. I can't get over how accomodating this place was. It's like they thought of everything. A few of my favorite things: breakfast delievered every morning in a picnic basket to your room, nice bathroom amenities, nice dishes for use in the kitchen, happy hour for guests (wine, cheese & beer) each night from 5-6, and a beautiful rooftop open to guests. I would love to stay here again sometime! The front desk attendant was very helpful with recommending places to go and things to do during our stay.This is the only place I will stay when in Charleston.  We have stayed here so many times and every stay is always great.  I consider the amazing staff and management first class all the way! I wish I lived here.Beautiful hotel smack in the middle of Charleston.Palmetto Bluff was a tough act to follow.  But, the Restoration on King delivered and then some.  It's right on the corner of King and Wentworth, steps away from all of the action and the best shopping in town.  Arriving early in the day, our suite wasn't ready.  They checked our bags for us and took our car.  After a quick lunch and a bit of sightseeing, we were all set.  And let me tell you, we were set.  We were greeted by Howard, the GM, who welcomed us and gave us some advice about town.  He mentioned the lobby wine ad cheese hour and how they had free iPads for guest use.  How cool is that?  Grabbed one of those right then and there, and tinkered with it our whole stay.  This loft conversion building looks as if it were intended to be condos.  We had a huge suite with more room than we really needed and amenities and touches we weren't expecting to have.  Our multilevel room included hardwood floors, a full kitchen with stainless appliances, W&D, living room, plasmas, ceiling fans, sound machine and even an outdoor patio.  The king bed was super comfy and we slept like babies to the sound of crashing waves from the Miami sound machine, which was an awesome touch.  The bath had a great shower, but only a single sink.  There is tons of space to put all of your stuff and outlets to charge all of the gadgets in your Batbelt, which included a big walk in closet.  We enjoyed beers on our patio lounge, but it just got too hot for us.  An umbrella or some kind of shade out there would have been perfect.  They really took care of us here.  Breakfast was delivered to the room in a picnic basket, the staff was helpful and welcoming at every turn and even flawlessly dealt with our early departure.  Which is more than I can say for the overwhelmed Charleston airport TSA.    We had a wonderful stay at the Restoration and certainly return when back in town.The Restoration on King is up there with the Five Pine Lodge in Sisters Oregon, the Hotel Del Coronado in San Diego and the Biltmore in Miami as one of the finest and most enjoyable hotels I've ever stayed in.It is a boutique hotel in every sense of the word - brilliantly appointed loft rooms, effortlessly friendly and gracious service, and an overall sense of relaxation and ease that it almost impossible to create. The rooms themselves are enormous, with full granite kitchens, comfortable seating areas and huge windows. The bed is excellent, tucked away in a lofted room. The bathroom is spacious and nicely appointed.The perks of staying there include a cheese reception at 5 and a cookie reception at 8, as well as a gratis breakfast delivered to your door every morning in a basket.If you are staying in Charleston, there is no better place for you to be.Wonderful wonderful wonderful hotel!!!!!! It is located right off of king street. Couldn't ask for a better location. The suites are beautiful and huge! Our suite was a one bedroom with a full AND a half bath, a living room, dining area and a full kitchen. Breakfast is delivered every morning to your room in a picnic basket. You fill out a menu the night before of all the food you want for breakfast. So amazing! Also, every evening wine and cheese are served between 5-6p and port is served a little later around 8p. The staff is so friendly and helpful. Can't say enough good things about this hotel. You must stay here when you visit Charleston.Fantastic hotel. Essentially, ROK is a boutique property comprised of one bedroom condos with more space than you'll get at almost all hotels in downtown Charleston. Here's the long list of reasons that led to 5 stars: - Perfect location off King - Very large, modern rooms - essentially luxury 1 bed condos w/ full kitchen & washer/dryer - Breakfast is included, but not some lame buffet. You choose off a menu and breakfast is delivered outside your door in a picnic basket.  Have never seen anything like it - awesome! - Internet is fast and simple to jump on - Great night's sleep - Staff was great - Wine & Cheese early evening & fresh baked cookies at night - Fantastic value - $229/night when the Renaissance wanted $199/night - no brainerIt's easy  to see why ROK is a Travelers' Choice 2012 Top 25 Winner.Home from home - loft style apartments. Excellent meet & greet and easy valet park to welcome you to this superb hotel alternative. The apartment I had was very spacious with excellent full kitchen facilities including in-room laundry appliances which was appreciated after 3 weeks touring around Florida & Georgia.The apartments are a good specification with all the usual home comforts. The hotel style services are professional with breakfast delivered to your room which was a nice way to start the day. I am only staying for a few days but could easily stay here comfortably for a longer period.The added bonus is that it is also located in the heart of the historic district by King St!!!!Beautiful hotel in a great location in downtown Charleston. The staff were very hospitable, particularly liked the picnic breakfast in the morning. The rooms as others have noticed are enormous, and it looks like this may have been built as a condo.We were in Charleston for a wedding and had a patio room, we had people over a couple of nights, and the place can easily handle 10 people in the living room.  We didn't use the patio, ended up using the roof deck since it had a much better view.I tried staying here for New Year's Eve.We made the reservations a few days before, showed up, but it didn't work out.  Apparently their online system is not synced with their front desk, and they overbooked.And while it still blows my mind that this can happen in 2011, they did the right thing. They were kind and apologetic.  And they booked (and paid for) us to stay at another nearby hotel.I'd still like to stay here someday.Wow!  This place is absolutely incredible!  Gorgeous room - great service.  Location can't be beat. Suite is very spacious - I even got a load of laundry in. Kitchen actually had refreshments,  and a wonderful breakfast was provided - which you selected. Staff was incredibly accommodating and knowledgeable - and I ask a lot of questions. Highly recommend, and reasonable considering all that is provided.
review_content_20: This hotel is absolutely amazing. The look and feel is so unique. The staff are so nice and were extremely helpful. We arrived to a fridge full of travel Cokes/Sprite/Water bottles for our walks down the wonderful King St, right in the heart of downtown Charleston.The hotel is located in the perfect part of the city. We literally did not use our car until we got back in it for the drive back home. You can walk just about everywhere you'd want to go on a three day trip.The rooms are huge! It has a loft feel and full of modern charm. The appliances were very nice and they had plates, silverware, mixing bowls and more if you wanted to cook while you're in town. They also offer to stock your fridge full of groceries if you call ahead and give a shopping list. They also provided a picnic basket full of food for breakfast every morning.We thought about using a bed and breakfast for our trip but we couldn't have been happier with where we stayed. I wish I could live in a place like this!This is one of the best hotels we have stayed in bar none.  We are very selective about accommodations, and this hotel satisfied us.  To begin with, we were told the "rooms" were originally intended to be sold as condos, but instead the owner decided on a boutique hotel.  With that, the rooms are actually apartments.  We had a one bedroom unit with a living room, kitchen, laundry room, and master bathroom.  The building's architecture is great, and each room is decorated with exposed brick, earthy tones, and refurbished wood floors; in other words, all of the charm of a Charleston building! The bed was ultra comfortable, and the pillows were great too; nothing like typical cheap hotel pillows.  A great night's sleep for all five nights we were there.  The hotel staff makes you want for nothing.  All requests were granted, and in a timely fashion.  When we checked in, we even were greeted with a chilled bottle of sparkling wine and a hand-written note welcoming us.  Each evening there is a breakfast menu in the room to fill out, and the next morning, a complimentary breakfast is delivered in a picnic basket to the door (nice touch!).  Each afternoon they have free wine and cheese in the lobby, and each evening free milk and fresh cookies.  As for location, you could not be more central in the city.  Everything in the city is within a five to ten minute walk.  King Street right outside the door is clearly the premier shopping area as there are many trendy stores and boutiques.  There are tons of restaurants in the area, and the staff of the hotel will make you reservations and recommend places as well.  Will definitely return to this hotel and Charleston.  A great place to visit, and a great place to stay.This is one of the nicest hotels I've ever stayed in. Valet parking, check. Beautiful lobby with wines and cheese, check. Escorted to my room, check. Gigantic room, check. Gigantic room that's bigger than my current apartment and is much nicer and cleaner and more spacious, check. Tour of my gigantic room that's bigger, nicer, cleaner yada yada yada and more spacious, check. For the first several hours, I was doing laps in the hotel just so I felt I used every inch of it. Great breakfast delivered in a picnic basket with a newspaper, check. The bed was really comfortable. The bathroom facilities were nice. A full kitchen. A washer & dryer. Beautiful view of King Street. Which leads to the best last point: the location. Right on King Street. I felt spoiled. And it was a nice feeling.AMAZING HOTEL! We stayed at this hotel for 5 days following our wedding. I travel a lot and have been told that I am "hotel bourgie" and I loved it here! It was beautiful. HUGE rooms, everything in the place looks new. Stainless  steel appliances, hard wood floors, very comfortable beds, spotless bathrooms. The service was amazing as well. The owner of the hotel is around all the time and is very friendly. He knew us by name by the 2nd day and offered tips on beaches and restaurants. The location can't be beat. It's near everything you want to do in Charleston. My husband and I loved it here and will definitely stay here on future trips to charleston!this place is pricey, and worth every penny.our 3rd room had a great view, comfy couch, 40" flat screen, full kitchen with marble counters, stainless steel full size fridge (great for those left overs) - lofted bed room with a big puffy comforter  breakfast (bagels, muffins, danish, coffee ) arrives in a picnic basket, and we had it on the roofnice afternoon wine and cheese, complimentary ipads/bikes -- wonderful room coffeemake sure to find the roof top deck, the view is worth every stepLet me start off by stating that I grew up in Charleston and go back every year to visit friends.  You get what you pay for!  Typically stay at places such as the Charleston Place, but after having sub-par service there for the last several years my wife decided we needed a change.  Great service started the moment we pulled the car up front of the hotel.  The bellman came right over and didn't even ask "do you need help with your bags", he simply said "we have it, just go on in and have some refreshments".  Contemporary and Charming is the best way to describe the lobby.  We did arrive early, so we expected the rooms to not be ready.  The staff locked up our luggage, took my cell phone number, and offered to call us when the room was ready (which they actually did).  The general manager (Howard) stopped by to welcome us and offered to help us get into any restaurants that we might be interested in.  Since we always meet up with friends, my wife had already taken care of hitting all of the hot spots months in advance.  Even though we were early, Howard cracked a couple of bottles of wine for my wife and another couple who were traveling this time with us.  Not going to bore everyone with all of our activities while we were down here, but do want ot point out a few things:Rooms - There are about 15 rooms located on the second and third floor.  The one bedroom is a loft style room and has a "Full" den and kitchen.  Like our good friends who were traveling with us, we have stayed in suites at the Four Seasons, The Ritz, etc., and I will tell you that these rooms are outstanding.  The whole layout screamed "relax here".Service - All of the staff was very attentive and were always trying to make sure we were happy.  Howard really did stand out in making sure that everyone was taken care of.  From something as simple as getting us some wine on the early side to arranging a bike taxi to pick up my wife and I within only 3 minutes of advance notice (as usual we were running late to a dinner engagement) and also at the same time getting someone up to our room to fix the automatic lock that decided to get stop working on the front door just as we were scrambling to get to the dinner.Extras - Every morning we had a picnic basket in front of our door with a USA Today paper and fresh items for us to enjoy.  Extra charge for this...$0.  Fridge is restocked with soft drinks and water by housekeeping.....and once again you didn't get nickled and dimed for this (its included).  Wi-Fi (while not the strongest signal of any place I have stayed) was included at no additional cost as well.  Wine tasting with fruit and cheese each day in the lobby and also night time cookies.     For those who you who enjoying hitting the gym, the hotel provides a daily free membership to Eco Fitness (about a block down from the hotel) as well.Finally, I would be remiss if I did not mention the furnished private rooftop to enjoy magnificient views of downtown.Typically we have stated at Charleston Place while visiting Charleston, but opted to try this new spot and were extremely impressed.  The hotel consists of 17 luxury condos that were converted to hotel rooms.  The room we stated in was spacious with high ceilings and a nice private balcony.  Valet parking was reasonable and staff was attentive.  They also deliver a newspaper and good complementary breakfast each day (coffee, juices, scones, muffins, fruit, granola, yogurt, etc).  Cheese and wine for free earlier on and free cookies later in the evening.  Location is excellent, close to the good shopping and a few steps away from the good restaurants.  This will be our new go-to lodging while visiting Charleston.  Its nice to have more space than a bland hotel bed; it would be excellent for a group of people as it provides a place to meet up.  Also, each unit has a full kitchen and several large, modern flatscreen TVs, etc.

review_content: In a city with very pricey accommodations, the Ansonborough Inn is a find. It's not cheap, but for what you get, it's wonderful. We stayed in a suite, which was huge and had a fireplace. The room decor does need to be updated, but the high ceilings, exposed brick walls and views to the Charleston streets more than makes up for it. There is a great rooftop deck and the staff was very friendly. If you don't want to drop $600 on a room in Charleston, but still be downtown in a historic inn, this is the place.Agreed with other reviews that the Ansonborough is at a crossroads. The price point doesn't fit the experience. It either needs to go whole hog, bump up the price and full realize the potential that it has. Or, it can lower the price and continue along as is. But it cannot maintain the status quo. If it does, it can expect a bunch of middling-to-bad reviews and that's not entirely fair to what the hotel has going on. Like I said, there's potential.I arrived at the hotel ready to relax. My flight from Nashville was fine. My trip to the hotel was pleasant (thanks to Maurice from R&S Limo). And, when I showed up at the front door, I was happy with what I saw: lots of brick, lots of plants, sufficient Southern character. Sounds good. I arrived a little later than expected on a hot Friday in mid-summer. I wanted a drink but was nearing the end of the cocktail. So, imagine my happiness when, after greeting me, the front desk offered me TWO glasses of wine so that I could get my check-in on in style. Things are looking up. They got better when I received an upgrade. It seems a couple of their Friday reservations canceled, so I was bumped to room 210. I like. The room itself had a lot of charm: extremely high ceilings, exposed beams, exposed brick, a small living area, a proper wooden desk... all good things. But, the room was only halfway there. The bathroom was serviceable, if not comparable to the first impression of the room. The refrigerator was bare, there was a sink in the corner of the room that didn't seem to go with the aesthetic and (most importantly), my sheets weren't properly laundered. There are few things as first-world-problematic as mealy sheets in an expensive room when you want to lay your head. Even worse, when I called to get new sheets -- that's all I received. I made my own king bed. Now, I am not too good to make my own bed. But, barring being eight years old and having chores to do or needing to impress house guests that I am a fully functioning adult, making the bed isn't something on my usual playlist and it, certainly, isn't something I expect to do when staying at a hotel. So, that was a let down. And the sheets... well, Oprah would not be giving them away as her favorite things any time soon. The doors/walls are fairly thin so if you're a light sleeper or are traveling to be/do the nasty, be warned.That said, I appreciated the historic charm of the hotel and proximity to downtown happenings. Given the outward character, I was surprised (in a good way) with the modern touches of the lobby. The glass elevator is a nice accent. The hotel serves breakfast and has a nice dining area complete with coffee, tea, water, and lemonade. Oh, and cookies. Fresh cookies are always a plus. You see what I'm talking about? Potential. Personally, I think given the ridiculous real estate and price point in Charleston, the Ansonborough just needs to give in to the market, raise the price, fix all the problems, and offer guests the experience they expect to have once they look at the website and do the math. Being stuck in the middle is doing no one (hotel included) any favors.Ansonborough Inn21 Hassel StCharleston SCWe recently spent four nights here and love the Charleston area. The Ansonborough inn is located within two blocks of market St and near the water. It is truly an architectural gem, decorated nicely and well maintained. The rooms were large and comfortable. It also has a rooftop terrace with a decent view of the river and bridge. We found the folks at the front desk to be extra friendly, knowledgeable and very helpful. The criticism I have is for the owners. If you're going to offer a continental breakfast do it right. The fruit was ok but the pancakes and eggs were horrible microwave stuff. Do your guests a favor and get a waffle iron and let the guests fix their own waffles. You might want to mention to the kitchen staff that they should be courteous to guests as well. I would have given Ansonborough 4 stars for the desk staff alone but the reason is a biggie and the single main reason people get a room. SLEEPING on fine linens! The sheets made the bed feel like a hospital bed. They were rough and worse yet, didn't fit the mattress. You guys really  need to spend a little more and get really good bedding. Urban Cowgill December 2015This place looks fantastic but I would not recommend staying here. I could clearly hear the conversations of the room next to us,  as well as their tv...and they weren't yelling. Road noise was also a big problem. It has gorgeous rooms and a rustic feel,  but the room noise is just too muchAt a lower price point, they'd get a 3.The good:-Comfy bed (not in the league of hotels at a similar price point, but comfortable. Crisp sheets with a moderate thread count)-really nice housekeeping staff (I stayed two nights, left the "do not disturb" sign and they kindly left me a basket of towels and shampoo outside my door)///my room was clean (my coworker, OTOH, found long hairs on his sheets)-gorgeous lobby with exposed beams and soaring atrium that makes you feel like you're about to enter a rustic chic boutique hotel...Only, you're not. I'm afraid the bad outweighs the good. The main thing: it really could use one of those hotel makeover guys in here. It's so incredibly outdated. For example, Andes mints left on the pillow and "do not disturb/maid clean room" signs that remind me of being a kid at a Holiday Inn circa 1982. Neither are a really big deal, but it's just to give potential guests an idea.My room on the first floor was dreary. It led right to the street (there's even a glass door to the street that you can't open, but it's still unsettling) and had no natural light, so the room was perpetually depressing. The ceilings have are wood-paneled. The carpet seems old. Each room has what seems to be mismatched old furniture (my room had shabby overstuffed love seat and arm chair, while my coworker's had a pleather couch and a table). The furniture is crammed in there and makes you feel claustrophobic. Don't expect a bathrobe (at this price point, I would) and towels are rough and thin. No mini bar. Not even a bottle of water, which is especially unacceptable, as waking up to a glass of tepid tap water is really not a great way to start the day. You can attempt to get some water in the hospitality room... if anyone fills the water thermos. Then there's the "work out room." Even a carefully placed mirror won't give you the impression that this is anything but a single treadmill, a single elliptical and a small cable weight unit in a florescent- lit closet. There isn't even a water cooler in there. Again, with the lack of accessible water. And a final note: it's family-friendly. Which isn't awesome when you're here for work (picture 6 am screams and shouts echoing around that beautiful atrium lobby). If you can get a room at a good discount, sure, go for it as it's not the worst place in the world. Do. Not. Pay. Their asking price. For that, you should be in a Westin or Omni, not a (barely) glorified La Quinta with a nicer lobby. Staying here should cost one half the price.Quirky place in a decent location. About a 10 minute walk to the main tourist area of King St. Our room (palmetto suite) was huge and outdated. For the price is expect at least a nice sofa or mini bar, but the brown velvet sofa had white gunk on it and the small fridge was iced over and empty. The grossest part was the carpet. It had so many splatters, stains and black marks.....it made me question the cleanliness of the entire place. Oh and the exposed brick wall behind our bed was crumbling and there was white dust behind the bed and night stands that was never cleaned up. The cover of one of the complimentary magazines in the room was covered in food splatters (not ours). This place is not cheap! In the end I left grossed out. Would not stay again.A charming hotel with a wonderful ambiance. The lobby is breathtaking as you enter, with a beautfiul fireplace and high ceilings with exposed beams. The Front Desk and Housekeeing staff were friendly with the perfect amount of Southern Charm. They were always accomodating and had wonderful suggestions regarding the area. The rooms were very comfortable. Breakfast is served every morning in the common area and a complimentary wine and cheese hour was an added bonus. I wish we could have enoyed the lovely roof deck, alas it was rainy the weekend we were there. The hotel is a quick walk to Historic Charleston's main attractions, such as the City Market and Rainbow Row. For late night snacks there is a 24 hour Harris Teeter directly next door. A beautiful hotel in one of the most beautiful cities.Beautiful restored building.... And then there's the road noise.Lovely post and been construction.... And then there the traffic noise.Kind, nice staff... And then there's the noise outside that starts at 5:30amLots of reasons to stay here..... If you don't need your sleep. And the there's the parking:(This hotel is the best deal within charleston proper. I'll give it that much. For the price, it is somewhat outdated. I understand the vibe they are going for and they've achieved it somewhat, it just needs a little rejuvenation. That being said, everyone within the hotel has been incredibly kind. They do their best to provide amenities (free breakfast, roof deck, cheese and wine hour). Everything has been incredibly clean and the neutrogena bath products are a nice touch. I don't think I would pony up the hefty price to stay here again. You can stay elsewhere about ten minutes away for a third of the price.Lovely hotel with very nice staff. Our 3rd floor room was very quiet, clean & elegant. The rooftop gathering space was a big plus. We also enjoyed the wine & cheese available in the evening. This hotel is walking distance to anywhere downtown.  We were able to head S on a run through parks and historic districts and head N to run the Arthur Ravenel Jr Bridge.If we visit Charleston again we will definitely choose Ansonborough Inn.restaurants within walking distanceWe recommend eating at 82 Queen for a nice couples lunch, Bay Street Biergarten for a nice brew pub, the Gin Joint for drinks, Fleet Landing for outdoor dining.As others have said, this hotel is in a good (not great) location, being right across from a 24 hour supermarket which is actually pretty handy, but about a 10-15 minute walk from the main tourist area. However, it is only 3-5 minutes away from the stop for the free trolley which takes one all over town.The room we had, 337, was on the corner of the third floor and was basically a one bedroom apartment with a large bedroom with a comfortable kingsize bed and lots of closet and drawer space, a spacious living area with a bar sink, small fridge and microwave, a table for four and a reasonably-new sofa and two old, dirty, wingback chairs with ottomans.  The living room and bedroom each had a 32-inch or so flat screen TV. We loved having the bathroom off the living area because one person could sleep and the other be in the living area and not disrupt the other.  Breakfast was pretty good with hard-boiled eggs being offered only on one of our five days and the only hot cereal being the instant oatmeal-type.  Pastries and breads were fine and the fruit was okay.  Wine and cheese in the evening (and their pimento cheese dip) were much better; good crackers and cheeses, decent wine and that delicious dip with a bit of a kick. However comfortable our room and  however friendly the front desk staff, the HUGE drawback was the WORST shower we have ever experienced - and we have traveled all over the world.  For $250 on the weeknight and $350 on Friday night, we should have a good shower!   When we told the front desk, they sent a maintenance man who went to the hardware store and changed out the shower head.  Now instead of a fine mist, we had a trickle of water - definitely not better.  Finally on the last day Daniel said he had a room we could change to, but we weren't going to do that since we were getting ready to leave.  Graciously, he put that room out of order and allowed us to shower there, which was a big improvement over our shower.  When the manager returned on Monday, I expected a call, apology and some reimbursement.  Basically, she inferred that we were complainers, that the next guests had no problem with the shower, and that the maintenance men and her all determined that nothing is wrong with it.  She gave us $170 compensation.  We are actually people who don't complain about things but having to use the barely-better tub faucet made us definitely crabby, especially since we had to deal with this for five days.Even in October, Charleston is muggy and warm so we really wanted a decent shower!!!  Bottom line, don't stay in room 337 or check the shower first before you stay in the room.  We believe customer service is a priority and for what they charge, should have done something better.  We won't be going back!P.S.  Free wi-fi worked great in all areas of the hotel.Great experience! My husband and I stayed on Christmas Day and there was a stocking on the bed filled with yummy snacks and candy. There was hot apple cider and cookies downstairs as well. Complimentary breakfast which is always a plus. Our room was awesome. We stayed in the Palmetto Suite which was HUGE! Larger than most studios I've seen in NYC. Good location not a bad walk to the restaurants, bars and shopping. I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Charleston.We loved loved loved this place! Its exactly what youd expect to find in Charleston. They even still do the mints on the pillows. The cheese and wine at 5pm is the cherry on top. The breakfast doesnt have much protein but the spread isnt bad. I got what I paid for and more. The location is great. Everything is 4-7 minutes away when walking.We had a wonderful stay at the Ansonborough for a long weekend in September. It is filled with charm and completely unique. Loved the rooftop patio and the wine and cheese hour every evening. Our room was very comfortable- the only complaint we had was the noise level. We tried to nap in the late afternoon and there seemed to be a lot going on throughout the hotel and on street outside. Otherwise, we had an AMAZING time and would definitely return!My wife and I visited Charleston this past Labor day weekend. We stayed at Ansonborough for 2 nights, and it was great. The decor is fantastic, the room we got was very nice and comfortable, the art in the building is great, and the fact that they have an included continental breakfast just tops it off. It's a bit out of the way from all of the main restaurants, but not more than a 15 minute walk from wherever you'd like to go. There's a nice 24 hour grocery store right next to the hotel as well.Rooms were about half the price of comparable hotels closer to the main attractions, but walking an extra 10 or 15 minutes was worth saving the money. It's a beautiful hotel, and the only negatives I can say about it is that the walls are VERY thin, we could hear and understand conversations in the rooms next to and above us. Overall, very nice, one of the best hotels I've stayed at, would return.Stayed August 2014What a perfect place for our girlfriend get-away!  There were 6 of us in 2 rooms, plenty of space in one of the "Premium Loft" and a "Double Luxury". The wine and cheese was wonderful, tasty and they didn't mind a bit when we took ours up to the roof terrace. One morning we did yoga on the roof too, a great spot. The decor is beautiful, an old-world feel with plenty of wood beams and paneling. But it's a renovated warehouse so no "old-world" plumbing or electric...Breakfast was more than we expected and the cinnamon buns! We all went off our diets for those. Friendly and helpful staff too. (Thank you Daniel and Carrie.)Tips: Prices are high in Charleston, this Inn was pricey for anywhere else but midrange for Charleston. There is a handy 24 hour big grocery store across the street, we didn't find any other quick place downtown to buy necessities. We didn't hear any noise from it except a trash truck one morning, no biggie considering the convenience. If you can, get a Premium loft! Well worth the minor up-charge. Earthling day spa was great and about a block down the street. Palmetto Carriage with the "Big Red Barn" for the horse carriage tours also is very convenient, just a block away. Liberty square and the aquarium where you catch the boat to tour Fort Sumter is also in easy walking distance, to the north.Really loved this inn...built in 1901.
